utterances: Oh, we'd like 'em to be bigger, but, yeah, we do…
We're playing at Chicago Blues Fest next month, as a matter of fact.
And, I'm wondering, did you have trouble selling yourselves as a…?
But not 1924.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Not that I was there then.
I don't know if we--in a way I think it was easier for us because we were different.
I think we--people paid attention to us because we were unusual.
Then we had to keep their attention by being, you know, being able to handle it.
But I think it really helped, don't you, Gaye?
Yeah, I think we were a novelty act at first, but you can't be a novelty act forever.
No.
That won't get you there.
No, your second song gets to be in trouble, there.
Yeah, let's just get some listeners involved in the conversation.
And this is Michelle(ph).
Michelle calling us from Livermore, California.
Wow.
That's right.
Hi, I just want to say I'm a big fan.
I went to Mary Washington College in Fredericksburg and graduated in '85--‘89.
Wow.
And so I saw a lot of your early concerts.
And what I was wondering if you could talk about--I know some bands like you all and Dave Matthews Band and some other folks, kind of started out in college towns.
And I wondered if you could talk about the influence of--you know, if that helps, how it's different from maybe starting out other ways?
It helps a lot, because when Gaye and I first started playing music together, I was just learning to play the piano.
And we used to sneak into Mary Washington College and use their pianos in their practice rooms.
Oh, wow.
That was a good thing for me.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Did the presence of the college also provide venues for you guys to play at?
Yeah, our first rally big gig was a show at the college and we opened for B.B.
King, and we thought we'd died and gone to heaven.
That was awesome.
Yeah.
You were there?
Yeah, I was, I was laughing my butt off when you played the Middle-Aged Blues.
I mean, even for a--you know 17,18-year-old it was hilarious.
Well, Michelle, thanks.
You still following the blues music out there in California?
You know, I'm afraid I haven't been.
I've got two small children, so some of that stuff's not really appropriate for…
Oh, what could be more appropriate when you've got small children?
(Soundbite of laughter)
You know, yeah, I do still listen to it some.
Yeah, I was thinking blues cap for women, what do they do, give you two small children?
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, that will give you the blues, I guess.
There you go, at least for a while.
There are moments; they have their good points.
Exactly.
I'll try to remember them.
Michelle, thanks very much for the call, appreciate it.
Well, Thank you.
Thank you all.
Bye.
Thank you.
Thanks.
Thanks.
